client_profile: Couple buying in Brussels with EUR 490,000-895,000 budget. Priorities: cafes and brunch, parks, and a quiet residential feel. Prefer 15-minute lifestyle with outdoor space and solid energy performance.
must_have: Minimum 1 bedroom with 60+ sqm usable space.
Private balcony or terrace for morning coffee.
Within a 15-minute walk to a sizable park.
Quiet street or rear-facing unit away from bar clusters.
EPC rating C or better with double glazing.
nice_to_have: South or west-facing outdoor space with good light.
Elevator access if above the 3rd floor.
Secure bike storage in the building.
Parking option or easy street parking permit availability.
Recent kitchen and bathroom updates with modern appliances.
red_flags: EPC rating E or worse indicating costly heating.
Unapproved alterations lacking urban planning compliance documents.
Persistent bar or tram noise audible inside with windows closed.
High co-ownership arrears or legal disputes in the association.
Announced roof, facade, or elevator works without a funded reserve.
contradictions: Quiet street preference versus living next to vibrant brunch spots.
Historic charm versus better insulation from newer builds.
Top-floor light and views versus reliance on an elevator.
Large terrace desire versus tighter EPC and higher heating demand.

top_districts.name: Ixelles (Elsene)
why: Brunch and bars around Place Flagey with Ixelles Ponds and Tenbosch Park nearby.
Fast trams at Flagey and Bailli, plus buses to EU quarter and city center.
watch_out: Nighttime noise and weekend crowds around Place Flagey can disturb lower-floor apartments.

top_districts.name: Saint-Gilles (Sint-Gillis)
why: Cafes by Parvis de Saint-Gilles with greenery at Parc de Forest within walking distance.
Tram 81 and Horta metro offer quick links to Louise and Gare du Midi.
watch_out: Steeper streets and older buildings may challenge accessibility and add stair-only walk-up constraints.

top_districts.name: Woluwe-Saint-Lambert (Sint-Lambrechts-Woluwe)
why: Quiet residential streets near Parc de Roodebeek and Woluwe Shopping with calm cafe options.
Tomberg and Roodebeek metro stations give swift access to Schuman and city center.
watch_out: Some buildings include older heating systems that increase energy costs despite favorable EPC labels.

questions_for_agent_landlord: What are the total purchase costs, taxes, and expected annual property charges?
Is the title and urban planning status fully compliant, including permits and cadastral data?
What are monthly co-ownership fees, reserve fund level, and planned works with budgets?
What is the condition of roof, facade, plumbing, and electrical, and when were inspections done?
What timeline, contingencies, and negotiation flexibility does the seller prefer for closing?
next_steps: Confirm mortgage pre-approval and total purchasing costs with your bank.
Shortlist 6 to 8 streets per district and set viewing priorities.
Book back-to-back viewings and collect EPC, PEB, and co-ownership documents.
Engage a notary for SPA review and timeline coordination.
clarifying_questions: How many bedrooms and minimum interior size do you need?
Do you require parking or an elevator for daily use?
Which areas should be within a 15-minute walk for daily routines?
action_plan: Confirm your top-3 areas by visiting 2 micro-anchors in each (day + evening).
Confirm full purchase budget: taxes, notary, agency fees, renovation buffer, and monthly charges.
Line up a trusted notary/agent and define your offer terms (conditions, timeline, financing).
Ask the agent/landlord the 5 essentials below and request written answers.
